question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors that could influence the outcome. Firstly, the Republican National Convention is a complex process where delegates from each state vote to select the nominee. While Donald Trump Jr. is a well-known figure in the Republican Party due to his father's presidency, the nomination process involves a dynamic interplay of various factors such as state primary elections, party politics, and delegate dynamics. Historically, the Republican Party has not traditionally favored younger family members of former presidents for the nomination. However, Donald Trump Jr. has been an active figure in Republican politics and has been involved in various party activities, which could potentially increase his visibility and influence. Moreover, the 2024 election is still in the future, and a lot can change between now and the convention. Other candidates may emerge, and the political landscape could shift due to various factors such as economic conditions, international events, and internal party dynamics. Given these considerations, it's challenging to assign a high probability to Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee. While he has a connection to the party through his father, the nomination process is inherently unpredictable and influenced by a multitude of factors.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks about the likelihood of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. The context provided suggests that there is a significant opposition within the Democratic Party to the early nomination plan, with Rep. Jared Huffman and others organizing a plan to speak out against it. The fact that a drafted letter has been circulated and that Rep. Huffman is actively involved in the effort suggests that there is a strong desire among some Democrats to express their opposition to the plan. However, it's also worth noting that the Democratic National Committee (DNC) has not publicly confirmed the existence of the letter, and it's unclear how many signatures have been collected so far. Additionally, the market resolution criteria require a public letter with at least 20 signatures from House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party, or multiple letters with a combined total of 20 signatures. Considering these factors, I would estimate that there is a moderate likelihood of at least 20 Democrats signing the letter, but it's still uncertain whether they will meet the market resolution criteria.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: There are already two safe-seat members who have publicly urged Biden to drop out, and two of the most endangered Democrats have written off Biden's chances to win in November. Additionally, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats that would call on Biden to end his campaign. This suggests that there is a significant amount of pressure building within the Democratic Party to drop Biden's campaign. Given the number of people involved and the level of coordination, it is likely that a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators will work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th.

question.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that the European Union will announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024, I'll consider several factors: 1. Trade tensions between the EU and China: The EU and China have had a complex trade relationship in recent years, with both sides imposing tariffs on each other's goods. The EU has been particularly concerned about the impact of Chinese imports on its domestic industries, such as the automotive sector. Given this context, it's possible that the EU might consider imposing new tariffs or duties on Chinese electric vehicles to protect its own industry. 2. EU's trade policy towards China: The EU has been increasingly critical of China's trade practices, including its industrial policies and intellectual property theft. The EU has also been pushing for greater reciprocity in trade with China, which could lead to new tariffs or duties on Chinese imports. 3. Electric vehicle market dynamics: The EU is a significant market for electric vehicles, and Chinese manufacturers have a substantial presence in this market. The EU's automotive industry has been lobbying for protectionist measures to address the perceived threat from Chinese imports. 4. Previous trade actions: In 2020, the EU imposed tariffs on certain Chinese goods, including solar panels and steel, in response to China's unfair trade practices. This suggests that the EU is willing to take action to protect its domestic industries. 5. Current events and announcements: There have been recent developments in the EU-China trade relationship, including the EU's announcement of a new investment screening mechanism for foreign investors, including Chinese companies. This could be a precursor to further trade measures. Considering these factors, while there is no concrete evidence of an imminent announcement, the probability of the EU announcing new tariffs or duties on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024, is not negligible.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: There are already two safe-seat members who have publicly urged Biden to drop out, and two of the most endangered Democrats have written off Biden's chances to win in November. Behind the scenes, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign. This suggests that there is a significant level of dissatisfaction among Democratic lawmakers with Biden's campaign, and that some are actively working to pressure him to drop out. Given the fact that there are already multiple individuals who have publicly expressed their desire for Biden to step down, and that there are behind-the-scenes efforts to draft letters and pressure him to drop out, it seems likely that a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators will work together to ask Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

While Trump's actions on January 6, 2021, could be considered an insurrection, it's unclear whether this would be a sufficient grounds for removal under Section 3. 2. Previous attempts to remove Trump from office: There have been several attempts to impeach or remove Trump from office, but none have been successful. This suggests that the political will to remove him from office may be lacking. 3. Some states may have more stringent requirements for removal than others. 5. Court decisions and legal challenges: Any attempts to remove Trump from the ballot would likely be met with legal challenges. The outcome of these challenges would depend on various factors, including the specific laws and regulations in each state. Given these factors, I believe that the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment is relatively low. While it's possible that some states may attempt to remove him, the legal and political challenges involved would likely make it difficult to achieve.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?

Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the 25th Amendment Section 4 being invoked before August 2024, I'll consider the following factors: 1. Current political climate: The question mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, which suggests there may be some level of political motivation behind the request. However, this doesn't necessarily imply that the invocation will occur. 2. Section 4 invocation process: The 25th Amendment Section 4 requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) to agree on the President's incapacitation. This process is relatively rare and typically involves a significant consensus among the Cabinet members. 3. Biden's health: While there have been concerns about Biden's age and health, there is no public indication that he is unable to discharge his duties as President. 4. Recent precedent: There is no recent precedent for the 25th Amendment Section 4 being invoked, which suggests that it is a rare and extraordinary measure. Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of the 25th Amendment Section 4 being invoked before August 2024 is relatively low. question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Scotland holding an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, I'll consider the following factors: 1. The UK government's stance on Scottish independence: The UK government has consistently shown resistance to Scottish independence, and it's unlikely they would sanction a referendum that could potentially lead to the dissolution of the union. 2. The Scottish National Party's (SNP) push for independence: The SNP has been a strong advocate for Scottish independence, but their efforts have been met with resistance from the UK government. While they may continue to push for a referendum, the UK government's opposition makes it difficult to predict a sanctioned referendum. 3. The current political climate: The UK is currently in a period of political uncertainty, with the Conservative Party in power and the SNP in opposition. This could lead to a more favorable environment for the SNP to push for a referendum, but it's still uncertain. 4. The possibility of a 'wildcat' referendum: While a 'wildcat' referendum is not considered a valid outcome, it's possible that the SNP or other pro-independence groups might attempt to organize an unofficial referendum. However, this would likely be met with strong opposition from the UK government, and it's unclear whether it would be successful. Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of a sanctioned referendum is relatively low. However, it's not impossible, especially if the SNP gains significant momentum or if the UK government's stance on Scottish independence changes.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:

* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

Firstly, the ICC has issued arrest warrants for high-ranking officials in the past, such as Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir in 2009 and Libya's Muammar Gaddafi in 2011. However, these cases were often related to international crimes committed during conflicts, and the ICC's jurisdiction is limited to situations where a state is unwilling or unable to investigate and prosecute these crimes. Secondly, the ICC has been critical of Israel's actions in the occupied Palestinian territories, particularly with regards to the settlements and the treatment of Palestinians. In 2021, the ICC's Office of the Prosecutor (OTP) announced that it had opened a preliminary examination into the situation in Palestine, which could potentially lead to investigations and arrest warrants. However, the ICC's decision to issue arrest warrants for Israeli leaders would require a significant escalation of the situation. The Israeli government has been resistant to ICC involvement, and it is unclear whether the ICC would be able to gather sufficient evidence to support an arrest warrant. Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of the ICC issuing arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024, is relatively low. While the ICC has the potential to take action, the Israeli government's resistance and the complexity of the situation make it a challenging and uncertain outcome.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

Given these factors, it's difficult to predict with certainty whether Tim Scott will be the Republican nominee. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

A brokered convention typically occurs when no single candidate has a majority of the delegates before the convention. Several scenarios could lead to this situation: a large number of candidates entering the primary, splitting the vote among them, making it difficult for any one candidate to reach a majority; a candidate dropping out unexpectedly, causing a shift in the delegate count; or alterations in the Democratic Party's primary process. However, there are also factors that could reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as reforms made by the Democratic Party to streamline the primary process and the emergence of a strong front-runner. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The plan to virtually nominate Biden early is controversial among some Democrats, as evidenced by the organizing effort by Rep. Jared Huffman and the drafted letter with multiple signatures. The fact that the letter has been circulated and has received attention from a lawmaker and Politico suggests that there is a genuine effort to express dissent within the party. Additionally, the context of the attempted assassination of former President Trump may have heightened concerns among Democrats about the nomination process. However, it's difficult to estimate the exact number of signatures that will be obtained, and the resolution of the market depends on a specific condition (at least 20 signatures) being met. Considering these factors, I would estimate that there is a moderate chance of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing the public letter.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the current political climate, the invocation of the 25th Amendment Section 4 is a significant and rare action that requires a majority of the Cabinet and the Vice President to agree that the President is unable to fulfill his duties. Additionally, Biden has shown no signs of incapacity that would warrant this action, and political motivations alone are unlikely to lead to a formal declaration. Therefore, the probability of this scenario occurring before August 2024 is quite low.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?

This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a brokered convention for the Democratic Party in 2024, I'll consider various factors that could influence the outcome. A brokered convention typically occurs when there is no clear winner in the primary elections, and the party's delegates are not committed to a specific candidate. This can happen if there are multiple strong candidates with a significant number of delegates, but no single candidate has a majority. In the 2024 election, the Democratic field is expected to be competitive, with several potential candidates vying for the nomination. However, at this point, it's difficult to predict with certainty which candidates will emerge as frontrunners or how the delegate count will shake out. That being said, there are a few factors that could contribute to a brokered convention. For example, if a large number of candidates enter the primary and none of them are able to gain a significant lead, it could lead to a situation where no candidate has a majority of delegates. Additionally, if there are significant divisions within the party, such as between moderate and progressive wings, it could make it more difficult for a single candidate to win the nomination. On the other hand, there are also factors that could reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention. For example, if one or two strong candidates emerge early in the primary process and are able to build a significant lead, it could make it more difficult for other candidates to catch up. Additionally, if the party's rules and delegate allocation system are designed to favor a clear winner, it could reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention. Given these factors, I would estimate the probability of a brokered convention for the Democratic Party in 2024 as follows.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the Democrats having a brokered convention in 2024, I'll consider several factors that could influence the likelihood of a brokered convention. A brokered convention typically occurs when no candidate has a majority of the delegates, forcing multiple rounds of voting to select a nominee. Several factors could lead to this scenario: 1. Number of candidates: A large number of candidates in the primary election could increase the likelihood of a brokered convention. If multiple candidates have a significant following, it's more likely that no one will reach the majority of delegates required to win the nomination outright. 2. Debate and campaign dynamics: The way candidates perform in debates, their campaign strategies, and the general dynamics of the race could influence voter preferences and delegate distributions. A strong performance by a candidate could consolidate support, while a weak performance could lead to a shift in support among delegates. 3. Delegate distribution: The distribution of delegates from each state's primary or caucus could also play a crucial role. If certain states' delegates are split among multiple candidates, it could lead to a more complex delegate count, increasing the likelihood of a brokered convention. 4. Party rules and thresholds: The Democratic Party's rules regarding the number of delegates required to win the nomination, as well as any thresholds for winning a state's delegates, could impact the likelihood of a brokered convention. If the rules are set to favor a clear winner, it's less likely that a brokered convention would occur. 5. External factors: External events, such as scandals, economic shifts, or global events, could influence voter preferences and potentially lead to a brokered convention. Given these factors, estimating the exact probability of a brokered convention is challenging without specific data on the candidates, their performance, and the delegate distribution. However, based on historical trends and the factors mentioned, I'll provide a probability estimate.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The European Union has been actively engaged in trade negotiations and policy-making regarding electric vehicles, particularly with regards to Chinese imports. The EU has been concerned about the impact of Chinese electric vehicles on its domestic market and has taken steps to address this issue. In recent months, there have been reports of potential tariffs or duties being considered by the EU on Chinese electric vehicles. However, I couldn't find any credible sources confirming that the EU has officially announced new tariffs or duties on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024. Given the complexity of trade policy-making and the EU's tendency to engage in prolonged negotiations, it's possible that an announcement could be made in the coming weeks or months. However, without concrete evidence, I'm inclined to assign a lower probability to this event occurring before the resolution date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Fidesz-KDNP maintains its EU plurality from Hungary in 2024 and (b) the EU announces new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met: (a) Following the 2024 European Parliament elections, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance secures more seats than any other single party or coalition, thereby maintaining the highest number of Hungarian seats in the European Parliament, according to credible sources; and (b) Before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of both conditions being met, we need to assess the likelihood of Fidesz-KDNP maintaining its EU plurality in Hungary in 2024 (condition a) and the EU announcing new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024 (condition b). For condition a, the outcome depends on the performance of Fidesz-KDNP in the 2024 European Parliament elections. While Fidesz-KDNP has been the dominant force in Hungarian politics, there are signs of growing opposition and potential fragmentation of the Hungarian political landscape. The party's popularity has been declining in recent years, and there are several potential challengers, including the united opposition parties. Given these factors, I would estimate the likelihood of Fidesz-KDNP maintaining its EU plurality as slightly less than 50%. For condition b, the EU's decision to impose tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles depends on various factors, including trade negotiations, economic considerations, and geopolitical developments. The EU has been increasingly critical of China's trade practices, and there have been reports of potential tariffs on Chinese imports. However, the EU's decision-making process is complex, and the timing and specifics of any tariffs are uncertain. I would estimate the likelihood of the EU announcing new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024, as around 40%. Considering these estimates, the probability of both conditions being met is the product of the individual probabilities, which is around 0.4 x 0.45 = 0.18 or 18%.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks whether the movie "Deadpool x Wolverine" will have the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie, surpassing the record set by the original "Deadpool" movie. Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for the film, with estimates ranging from $340 million to $360 million globally. However, the current record for the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is held by the original "Deadpool" movie, which earned $284.5 million globally. To resolve this question, we need to wait for the actual box office numbers to be reported by a reliable source, such as the Hollywood Reporter. The resolution criteria are clear: the market will resolve YES if the movie grosses more than $284.5 million globally this opening weekend, according to reports, and the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release. I assign a probability of 0.7 to the question resolving YES because, while the analysts' projections are optimistic, the current record held by the original "Deadpool" movie is a significant benchmark. However, the movie is expected to play at more theaters and has a strong cast, which could contribute to a strong opening weekend. Additionally, the resolution criteria are clear, and we can wait for the actual box office numbers to be reported to determine the outcome.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Mike Pence will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider the current political landscape and the factors that influence the selection of the nominee. The Republican National Convention is a critical event that determines the nominee, and it's essential to analyze the potential candidates, their chances, and the dynamics within the party. As of now, it's difficult to predict with certainty who will be the nominee, as the field of candidates is likely to evolve over time. However, we can consider some factors that might influence the outcome: 1. Mike Pence's past experience and popularity: As a former Vice President and a well-known figure within the Republican Party, Mike Pence has a strong foundation to build on. His experience and popularity might give him an advantage in the selection process. 2. Current Republican Party dynamics: The Republican Party is known for its conservative leanings, and Mike Pence's views align closely with those of the party's base. This might make him a more attractive candidate to the party's delegates. 3. Considering these factors, it's challenging to assign a high probability to Mike Pence being the nominee. While he has a strong foundation, the Republican National Convention is a complex and unpredictable event, and many factors can influence the outcome.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that the Greens–EFA political group will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, I will consider various factors that might influence the outcome. The European Parliament elections are a complex process, with multiple parties and coalitions vying for seats. The outcome will depend on the voting behavior of citizens in each member state, as well as the electoral systems used in each country. The Greens–EFA group has been gaining popularity in recent years, and they have a strong presence in several European countries. However, they still face stiff competition from other established parties, such as the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). Given the complexity of the electoral process and the competitive landscape, it is difficult to make a precise prediction about the outcome. However, I can consider some general trends and factors that might influence the result. One factor to consider is the growing popularity of the Greens and other environmental parties across Europe. This trend might contribute to the Greens–EFA group gaining more seats in the European Parliament. On the other hand, the EPP and S&D groups have a strong presence in many European countries and might maintain their influence. Another factor to consider is the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the ongoing economic crisis on voter behavior. These factors might lead to increased support for populist or nationalist parties, which could potentially erode the support for more centrist parties like the Greens–EFA. Despite these uncertainties, I will attempt to provide a probability estimate based on my analysis. I will consider the historical performance of the Greens–EFA group in European Parliament elections, as well as their current popularity and influence in various European countries.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

First, OpenAI has a history of expanding its services to new regions, including the EU. The company has been actively working on global expansion, and it's likely they will continue to do so. Additionally, the fact that the question specifies 'generally available' implies that OpenAI may have already taken steps to make the service accessible to a significant portion of the EU population. Furthermore, the question does not mention any specific technical or regulatory hurdles that would prevent OpenAI from making the service available in the EU. However, I should also consider the fact that the question is asking about a specific date, June 30, 2024, which is relatively far in the future. This introduces some uncertainty, as there may be unexpected delays or issues that could arise. Nevertheless, based on OpenAI's past behavior and the information provided, I believe it is likely that ChatGPT will be available in the EU by that date.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Jared Huffman (D-Calif.). This indicates that there is a genuine effort to organize opposition to the early nomination plan. However, the resolution of the market depends on the actual number of signatures gathered by the end of Sunday, July 21st. question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, I'll consider several factors. First, a brokered convention typically occurs when there is no clear front-runner or when the party's nomination process is highly contested. In 2024, the Democratic field is expected to be crowded, with multiple candidates vying for the nomination. However, the party's nomination process has been modified in recent years to include more debates and earlier voting, which could reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention. Another factor to consider is the party's rules and procedures. The Democratic Party has implemented reforms aimed at preventing brokered conventions, such as the 'superdelegate' system, which reduces the influence of unpledged delegates. Additionally, the party has moved its primary schedule earlier in the election cycle, which could help to clarify the field and reduce the likelihood of a contested convention. However, there are also factors that could contribute to a brokered convention. For example, if a clear front-runner emerges but fails to secure the necessary delegates, or if a candidate drops out and their supporters are unable to coalesce behind a new candidate, it could lead to a contested convention. Given these factors, I would estimate the probability of a brokered convention as relatively low, but not impossible. I would assign a probability of 0.2, indicating a 20% chance that the Democratic Party will require more than one round of voting to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The information provided suggests that there is a significant number of House Democrats who are organizing a plan to speak out against the early nomination of President Joe Biden. A drafted letter has been circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, which indicates that scores of Democratic members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy. This implies that there is a strong opposition to the early nomination plan within the Democratic Party. However, the resolution of the market depends on the actual number of signatures on a public letter opposing the plan, which is not explicitly stated in the provided context. While the draft letter and the efforts of Rep. Huffman suggest that there is significant opposition, it is unclear whether this opposition will translate into actual signatures on a public letter. Considering the time frame and the context, I would estimate that there is a moderate probability of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given that public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, this suggests that Trump performs significantly better against Biden in polls than against generic Democrats. Since Manifold respondents would be voting with a real person (Joe Biden) rather than a generic opponent, it's possible that their responses might resemble their views on a specific presidential candidate rather than their opinions on a generic member of a party. On the other hand, assuming the respondents are representative of the general public, then according to public opinion polls Joe Biden would be considered out of the margin of error with Donald Trump (that is, Joe Biden typically performs worse than 5 points below Trump in polls). As such, it is unlikely that Trump would gain more than 3% of votes when voting with Biden rather than a generic democrat.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
